bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: November Boughs (1888); Newspaper clippings with corrections and notations
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839-1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

The prose drafted on the back of these and several other related manuscript leaves includes ideas and phrases that resemble those used in "Unnamed Lands," a poem published first in the 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass.

body.p: y Morning, June 11—On a sandthe St. Clair flats, where we had been stuck for a couple of hours.We passe'ˇd down Lake Huron yesterday and last night, and between 4 and 5 o'clock this morning we ran on the "flats," and have been mainly trying, with the aid of a steam and a lumbering lighter, to get cl again. The day is beautiful and ther clear and calm. Night before last we stoppedt at Mackinaw, (the island and town,) and I went up on the old fort, one of the oldest stations in the Northwest. We expect to get to Buffalo by to-morrow. The tug has fastene'ˇd lines to us, but some have been snappedt and the others have no effect. We seem to be firmly imbedded in the sand. (With the exception of a larger boat and better accommodations, it amounts to about the same thing as a becalmment I underwent on the Mountauk voyage, East Long Island, last summer.) Later.—We are off again—expect to reach Detroit before dinner.

We did not stop at Detroit. We are now on Lake Erie, jogging along at a good round pace. A couple of hours since we were on the river above. Detroit seeme'ˇd to me a pretty place and thrifty. I especially liked the looks of the Canadian shore opposite and of the little village of Windsor, and, indeed, all along the banks of the river. From the shrubbery and the neat appearance of some of the cottages, I think it must have been settled by the French. While I now write we can see a little distance ahead the scene of the battle between Perry's fleet and the British during the last war with England. The lake looks to me like a fine sheet of water. We are having a beautiful day.

June 12.—We stoppedt last evening at Cleveland, and though it was dark, I took the opportunity of rambling about the place; went up in the heart of the city and back to what appeare'ˇd to be the courthouse. The streets are unusually wide, and the buildings appear to be substantial and comfortable. We went down through Main street and found, some distance along, several squares of ground very prettily planted with trees and looking attractive enough. Returne'ˇd to the boat by way of the lighthouse on the hill.

This morning we are making for Buffalo, being, I imagine, a little more than half across Lake Erie. The water is rougher than on Michigan or Huron. (On St. Clair it was smooth as glass.) The day is bright and dry, with a stiff head wind.

We arrived in Buffalo on Monday evening; spent that night and a portion of next day going round the city exploring. Then got in the cars and went to
125 3 Niagara; went under the falls—saw the whirlpool and all the other sights.

Tuesday night started for Albany travele'ˇd all night. From the time daylight afforded us a view of the country all seeme'ˇd very rich and well cultivated. Every few miles were large towns or villages.

Wednesday late we arrived at Albany. Spent the evening in exploring. There was a political meeting (Hunker) at the capitol, but I passeˇd it by. Next morning I started down the Hudson in the Alida; arrived safely in New York that evening.
